name: Crochues-Berard Traverse
description:
From the top of the Floria Drag Lift, ski north for 20 metres and put skins on and skin northwards towards the Col Crochues. After around 250 metres of height gain it is usually necessary to take skins off and bootpack the remaining 50 vertical metres up to the Col. Crampons are generally not required for the bootpack but may be useful in icy conditions. 

From the Col, make a long descending traverse rightwards, passing under the Aiguilles Crochues west face and the Pointe Alphonse Favre south face to reach a large shoulder at c.2300 metres at the foot of the Pointe Alphonse Favre's west ridge. The latter part of this traverse is exposed so take care and keep concentrating all the way!

Once at the shoulder, put skins back on and climb north-east up to the Col de Berard. From here, descend the wonderful Berard valley to the tree line. There are countless variations which can be taken to reach the tree line. Once there, stay right of the river and ski to the hamlet of Le Buet via a good track and the occasional tricky section of tight tree skiing. From Le Buet, take the train back to Les Praz and the Flégère carpark.
access: Take the Floria and ski down slightly before hiking as detailed in the main description
short_description: A good introduction to Chamonix ski touring which nonetheless features a short bootpack and a slightly exposed traverse.

name: Couloir Bonatti
description:
This couloir is hidden deep in the Miage glacier and is probably the most repeated couloir in this area because it's often in good condition. This couloir can be reached by Arp lift and then a long skin. Leaving the lift stay on your right without losing height to reach the ridge. Here keep traversing on your left until reaching a flat part, where with your skins or walking (10 mins) you will arrive on a flat bowl. Put your skis on and start descending keeping your left until you reach a small bridge. Put your skins back on and start climbing up right in front of you to enter Miage glacier. In 1 - 1.5 hours you will reach the base of the couloir, where the true fatigue will start! You will have to bootpack the 1000 metre couloir, with the cold north wind coming down from it. The last 200 metres can be really rocky and the slope steepens up. It can be useful to have 30 metre rope to bypass this point.

The way back follows the glacial moraine, just follow back your skin track until you reach the bridge. Here continue following the evident road that will bring you to Val Very lifts. The lifts close at 4.30pm, but you can also keep skiing the road in order to reach the Courmayeur parking area.
short_description: A steep, wide couloir

content_proofreading.reason: The approach description needs to be more clear and have concrete details. Also, is it really possible to ski down Val Veny back to the parking area? I don't remember this being possible.

name: The Magic Forest
description: From the top of the Retour Pendant chairlift, ski down the Arolles piste then turn right onto the Chamois piste. After c.50 metres, drop off this left and ski through trees to a jeep track. There are numerous variations and options for routes to reach the jeep track. Turn left and traverse back to the foot of the Retour Pendant chairlift via some short sections of poling and side stepping. Don't be tempted to carry on downhill past the jeep track or you will end up in very tight trees and there are no more lifts to take back up!
short_description: A fun mini-adventure through the forest below Plan Roujon, with some steep drop-offs, this is particularly good in powder.

name: Poubelle Couloir
description:
Coming off the Bochard lift in the Grands Monetes ski area, the fence 20 metres down the piste which keeps people from falling down to the Pas de Chevre often appears to be THE social hang-around spot up there. Why? It is of course a scenic spot, but the party certainly starts whenever a skier climbs over the fence, clicks into their bindings and waves goodbye to the crowds by dropping into this line. The Poubelle couloir is a crowd catcher as well as a pretty rad line to choose to enter the Pas de Chevre. 

The narrow couloir makes for an impressive ski descent but is unfortunately often in bad condition when tracked out due to its southerly aspect that allows the sun to work the snow. However, in good snow, the Poubelle couloir can be a real treat and makes us wish that it was a bit longer than its length of 300 vertical meters.
An abseil is often needed ( roughly 30 metres) to enter the Poubelle due to exposed rocks or ice at the top. Because most people abseil in from the fence regardless of snow condition in the top, ski conditions can often be bad near the top of the line. If you are going for the abseil, please go backwards, down the fall line and with skis on and save the snow for stronger riders who want to enjoy the steep turns from the top!

With a steep angle up to 45 degrees in a narrow setting between the rock walls, the Poubelle couloir makes for descent that needs to be taken seriously. A fall in the couloir can have very serious consequences, hitting the sidewalls and skiers need to take good care and master their jump turns. There is an adjacent couloir that connects with the Poubelle skiers left side and falling snow/rock from here and above is possible. 
Depending on the snow cover, there can sometimes be a rocky step to manage midway down the couloir and caution is required for hidden rocks or unexpected hard snow/ice.
The Poubelle couloir skis best after snowfall and in the early winter when the daytime temperature stays low. Watch out for avalanche risk. 
At about 2400 meters, you exit the Poubelle couloir and join the normal descent of the Pas de Chevre.
location: From the top of the Bochard godola of teh Grands Montents, ski 100m SW and gain the fence to the Poubelle Couloir.
short_description: One for the poseur! A much-eyed line down a spectacular couloir. Not to be under-estimated

name: Ducroz 4
description: D4
short_description: D4

name: Hangar Couloir
description: The right hand entrance to the Passerelle offers a wider entrance which tends to be less scraped out due to a bit more space for skiers to enjoy.
short_description: A steep, serious variation leading in to the classic Passerelle couloir.

name: Grand Mur
description: A hidden gem; varied and interesting skiing high above the Argentiere Glacier
short_description: A hidden gem; varied and interesting skiing high above the Argentiere Glacier

name: Italian Bowl
description: Another classic Grands Montets line, accessing a hidden bowl below steep cliffs
short_description: Another classic Grands Montets line, accessing a hidden bowl below steep cliffs

name: Posettes Couloirs
description: Long consistent couloirs offer amazing skiing. From the top of the Laicuillette lift traverse hard right maintaining your height to the ridge line. Turning the corner choose from one of these classic couloirs which can offer exceptional and sustained skiing all the way to the valley floor. Traverse back to the Vallorcine station. These couloirs are steep and very prone to avalanche.  Make sure you know the conditions before you set out.
short_description: Long consistent, but serious couloirs offer amazing skiing.

name: Moraine des Rognons
description: An interesting direct line through the moraine wall to the Argentiere Glacier
short_description: An interesting direct line through the moraine wall to the Argentiere Glacier

name: Pas de Chevre Variation
description: A equally fine variation on the legendary Pas de Chevre. Serious skiing in a spectacular big mountain environment
short_description: A equally fine variation on the legendary Pas de Chevre. Serious skiing in a spectacular big mountain environment

name: Aiguille Pourrie
description: Not often in condition but worth the hike out to this spectacular summit. Classic location for the Freeride World Tour. From the top of the Col Cornu chairlift skin up to the col itself and follow the ridge to the summit of the Aiguille Pourrie. This usually involves a skin and/or bootpack. From the summit ski in a NE direction tending left to avoid most of the rocky sections (many variations) before entering the Combe Gliere. Enjoy some fast mellow terrain before re-joining the piste. Beware of avalanche risk.
short_description: Not often in condition but worth the hike out to this spectacular summit. Classic location for the Freeride World Tour.

name: Aiguille D'Entreves
description: A short hike leads to this incredible run. Steep up high and open in the lower it simply begs you open up full throttle. Start as for the Vallee Noir via Glacier du Geant  - From the Helbronner head out left along to the Col des Flambeaux. From the col traverse left towards the Aiguille de Toule and down the steeper pitch to its right. The Line starts here. On the plateau below the north side of the Aiguille de Toule put on you skins etc and head up left to the Col d'Entreves. Here you usually need to put on crampons and get your axe to climb the first section of the south ridge. When you meet a steep rock step traverse this on the right, rope sometimes useful. Traverse at this height further right until the whole east face opens out below you. Get your skis back on and ski the steep face below pulling to the left as ridge divides the tarrain below. The second half of the face opens back out to your left is slightly lower angled and with a more NE aspect often holds exceptonal snow. Ski down onto the glacier below and rejoin the Toule Glacier line.   Beware the approach requires skins and covers crevassed terrain.
short_description: A short hike leads to this serious but incredible run. Steep up high and open in the lower it simply begs you open up full throttle.

name: Couloir Allais
description: Less steep than some of the Brevent couloirs but not to be underestimated. Although shorter than the other Brevent couloirs the Allias offers a wider canvas pefect for opening up.  After following the "Charles-Bozon" piste hang a right before "Altitude 2000" into the wide couloir leading you into the Brevent bowl and then the track back to Planpraz.
short_description: Although shorter than the other Brevent couloirs the Allias offers a wider canvas pefect for opening up.

name: Pisteurs
description: A short steep hanging snowfield, approached by a scramble over the Grands Montets summit
equipment: Ice axe, crampons, possibly a rope for the approach across a narrow rocky ridge
short_description: A short steep hanging snowfield, approached by a scramble over the Grands Montets summit

name: Plan Joran Ridge 1
description: A nice run slope with sparse trees
short_description: A nice run slope with sparse trees

name: Rectiligne Couloir
description:
The Rectiligne couloir is a classic Chamonix steep ski descent off the Grands Montets and down towards the Glacier du Nant Blanc, beneath the mighty Drus mountains.
With its easy access from the Grands Montets top station it sees many descents but should not be underestimated despite this. The couloir is steepest at the top (about 45 degrees for a short section at the entrance) followed by 300 meters of 42 degrees. The entrance is - depending on the snow coverage - sometimes a bit rocky and can require some careful down climbing or a short rappel over the steepest section to get in. It is also most narrow at the top and skiers will need to perform a couple of neat jump turns. The couloir quickly opens up a bit allowing for bigger turns when the snow is good, yet, surrounded by steep rock walls, it feels narrow and offers an experience of skiing enclosed by the mountain in a wild setting.

Ski down the Nant Blanc glacier in the middle of the snow covered moraine ridges, keeping to its right bank to about 2400 meters where it the Pas de Chevre joins this route. Traverse the glacier to skiers left at about 2300 meters. Cross the moraine ridge left and ski down to the trees, keeping skiers left of the Torrent de Bayer, to an opening in the trees at about 1900 meters that leads down to some birch trees with an old rope. The following section may require a short abseil to get onto the top ridge of the moraine, which is often icy. A plateau ledge on the top of the moraine banks above Mer de Glace leads south for about 200 - 300 meters until you can enter the moraine slopes and ski down to the Mer de Glace. There are several possible variants to ski down the moraine depending on snow coverage.

Note! Make sure that the snow cover on the moraine above Mer de Glace is good enough for skiing before you go here. This is a very dangerous part of the descent due to the potential of falling rocks and you should not venture out here unless the moraine is well covered in snow! 

Regardless of its easy access and increasing popularity, the Rectiligne couloir takes place in a high mountain environment and requires glacier knowledge, some ski mountaineering skills and navigation skills. Be careful of the bergschrund in early season when it is not filled in, as well as the big crevasses further down the Nant Blanc glacier.

Gear such as glacier equipment, rope, harness and ice axe, are mandatory. Often a rope is needed to exit the trees below the Nant Blanc glacier (15 meter abseil) and onto the moraine ridge that leads down to Mer de Glace. Sometimes a rope is needed also for the top or in early season to manage the bergschrund or the final step out of the couloir that can be icy. In these conditions it is advisable to bring some cord and rock protection to build an anchor, there is no in situ gear. In normal snow coverage it is easy to ski out of the couloir.

Join the Mer de glace, cross over and go either to the Montenvers or ski another 500 horizontal metres down the glacier to gain the trail leading up to the café/buvette and the James Bond track back to town.
access: From the Grands Montets top station, ski down west on the Glacier du Grands montets to 3009 meters elevation. Look for a narrow couloir SW from this point, with prominent rock on each side. This is the top of the Rectiligne couloir.
location: Aiguille des Grands montets, Glacier de Grands Montets, in direction of Pas de Chevre, the narrow SW couloir with entrance at 3009 meters on glacier de Grands Montets.
short_description: A steep, narrow couloir in wild high mountain terrain

name: Couloir de la Jeureumaz
description: A steep couloir through the forest, narrow in places
short_description: A steep couloir through the forest, narrow in places

name: L'Aiguillette Des Posettes, South side
description: A real adventure as you traverse and ski fantastic terrain all the way to the valley floor. From the Posettes lift traverse hard right following the flowing terrain above the avalanche barriers before linking clearings all the way to the valley floor. A real adventure. To be undertaken early in the day before the South facing slopes get cooked!  Be aware of the steep cliff faces beneath you.  Be sure you look at the route and conditions on the way up the lifts.
short_description: A real adventure as you traverse and ski fantastic terrain all the way to the valley floor.

name: Couloir des Bucherons
description: A twisting gully through the trees; often gets very bumpy in the stream-bed
short_description: A twisting gully through the trees; often gets very bumpy in the stream-bed

name: Canadian Bowl
description: A classic Grands Montets line; open, varied, great skiing
short_description: A classic Grands Montets line; open, varied, great skiing

name: Derby
description: A good run on wide open slopes
short_description: A good run on wide open slopes

name: Dome
description: A wide open glacier run with a steep exit
short_description: A wide open glacier run with a steep exit

name: Toula Glacier
description: Leaving the Punta Hellbronner top station head for the Col des Flambeaux. Traversing left side step through the col and continue to the Col oriental de Toula and take the stairs down onto the glacier from where you start this most amazing ski descent. Ski fall line until the terrain steepens and a crevasse field is passed on your right. After this stay close to the rock and ski ever-widening slopes always tending gently left as you explore this winter wonderland and make your way back to the mid station psyched for another lap.  The terrain is glaciated and extremely avalanche prone. The aspect gets lots of sun and don't be tempted to do one lap too many when the conditions start getting dangerous.
short_description: A serious but truly exceptional, long and varied ski descent in breathtaking terrain.

name: Combe a Germain
description: A narrow hidden bowl at 35 degrees
short_description: A narrow hidden bowl at 35 degrees

name: Couloir Philippe
description: A steep, narrow couloir through the lower forest; rarely skied
short_description: A steep, narrow couloir through the lower forest; rarely skied

name: Combe des Rachasses
description: A wide open glacier run in a small dip below the bounding cliffs
short_description: A wide open glacier run in a small dip below the bounding cliffs

name: Face
description: An imposing line down the small glacier at the top of the front face of the Grands Montets
short_description: An imposing line down the small glacier at the top of the front face of the Grands Montets

name: Les Rognons
description: A serious glacier run in the spectacular Argentiere Glacier basin
short_description: A serious glacier run in the spectacular Argentiere Glacier basin

name: Mallory
description: VERY EXTREME skiing.  Danger of death.  Exit the Aiguille du Midi cable car station and after walking down the ridge take a hard left traversing onto the north face. Descend the narrow face below you sticking to the side of the rocky outcrop before going going slightly left as the angle backs off. Another small pitch leads you into steepening terrain at which point traversing hard right will bring you into a rock garden and eventually a steep narrow gully leading you to a small col. Take a right onto some of the routes steeper terrain and after skiing down and gently left a technical travers left, passed with a short  rappel or some serious shuffling with bring you to the top of the Pan de Rideau. This large slope is incredible riding and not as steep as it looks. Ski the slope and head left at the bottom to work through a narrow choke - again a small rappel can be made here after which a long left hand traverse and short side step brings you to a 20 meter rappel that puts you in the last couloir giving steep yet relatively relaxed skiing that brings you back to the the Cosmique couloir route and the midstation.
short_description: Maybe the most coveted line in the Chamonix valley representing the pinnacle in steep and committing skiing, all with a perfect view of the town of Chamonix.

name: Pas de Chevre
description: A legendary Chamonix off-piste run. Serious skiing in a spectacular big mountain environment
short_description: A legendary Chamonix off-piste run. Serious skiing in a spectacular big mountain environment

name: Plan Joran Gully 1
description: A fun line down a narrow twisting gully
short_description: A fun line down a narrow twisting gully

name: Lachenal bowl
description: From the top of the Index chairlift hang a left into this combe that is often a pisted red run. Break right into the wider slopes to enjoy this classic off piste itinerary down into the Combe de la Glière. Many options exist, enjoy the flowing terrain before re-entering the piste.
short_description: Long fall-line skiing straight off the lift.

name: James Bond Track
description: Enjoy the 4x4 track 'James Bond' style all the way back down to Chamonix.  It is not always in good condition early or later in the season - be sure it is OK before planning on going down this way or you are in for an incredibly long walk! When snowy and in good condition, the line features countless fun hairpins and fast straights through the forest.
short_description: The "James Bond" track; hero skiing home after the Vallée Blanche

name: Envers du plan glacier
description: From above the Petit Rognon traverse down and left across open slopes to meet the Grand Envers line. A fun line.
short_description: A traversing section that links the Envers du Plan to the Grand envers and requin hut couloirs exit.

name: EDW's Marbré Descent
description: EDW's Marbré Descent
short_description: EDW's Marbré Descent

name: Marbree Couloir
description: Heading right from the Hellbronner top station go towards the Aiguilles Marbrées and traverse to the left of the peak and gain the entrance to the couloir here. Skins are required to access this descent as the approach is (gentle) uphill. Ski into the main couloir from the left side and once in the centre enjoy the fall line skiing . As the terrain kicks back traverse left over a large plateau. Once on the other side ski open terrain tending right to avoid massive cliffs. Once past these, track back left as you hug the rock walls and ski down and left into the forested area taking the line of least resistance through the forest, eventually skiing out onto the road before walking back to the La Palud.  Warning: very avalanche prone.
short_description: Probably the most spectacular descent on the Hellbronner, this line goes through some huge terrain and features steep freeriding.

name: Vormaine Gullies
description: The Vormaine gullies are easily accessed by traversing left off the Les Autannes lift. Once at the top of the gullies it is easy enough to traverse into several different ones and all provide great freeriding and lead back to the Vormaine beginners piste. The gullies can be avalanche prone so despite their proximity to the lift, they demand respect and require good conditions in order to be safe.
short_description: A series of gullies offering great skiing with a lot of variety and options, all easily accessed from a lift.

name: Dent du Géant
description: fatmap episode 1
short_description: fatmap episode 1

name: La Noire - North Face
description:
A not well known and infrequently skied steep line in the middle of the Vallée Blanche, La Noire is a 800m face that can be easily seen from the bottom half of the Vallée. The descent is quite technical and steep; the first part is above a big serac hanging behind the Dent du Géant. Usually this first part is icy, so knowledge of recent conditions and a careful approach are vital! The second part of the face moves though a labyrinth of rocks and cliffs. An abseil is usually needed to enter the third part of the face (red arrow on the photo) and there is no in-situ equipment so experience in finding and creating abseil anchors is required. In order to ski out the face there are several possibilities; if there is enough snow the easier way is to enter the big couloir just under the face. If there is not much snow, it is required to cross to the skiers left the bottom part of the face, and find a route down through the rocks.

Equipment required:
Ice axe, crampons, harness, ice screws, rope (50m), rappel gear (the rappel must be set up from the alpinists, there are no bolts on the rocks), glacier safety equipment,

Reaching this route is not easy and there are two different ways: 
1) From Hellbronner go towards the Dent du Géant, then enter the Vierge for few hundred meters. On the right there is a small steep couloir that brings you to the middle of La Noire's north face. Once on the face you can either ski straight away or bootpack up to the top of the face and ski from there.

2) From Aiguille du Midi, ski the first part of the Vallée Blanche and then skin up in the direction of the Vierge to reach the small steep couloir.
access: 1) From Hellbronner go towards Dente del Gigante, then enter the Vierge for few hundred meters. On the skiers right there is a small steep couloir that brings to the middle of the north face. Here you can either go down or climb up the last few meters to reach the top of the face.  2) From Aiguille du Midi, ski the first part of the Vallée Blanche and then skin up direction Vierge. Reach the couloir and then hike up as in the Helbronner description.
short_description: A hidden pearl under Dent du Géant featuring some wild, exposed skiing and requiring a wide range of ski mountaineering skills.

name: Vrai Vallée Blanche
description: Follow the Vallee Blanche to just before the Col du Gros Rognon then ski down left under the north face of the Gros Rognon, following weaknesses between the more crevassed sections. Rejoin the classic Vallee Blanche under the Gros Rognon.  Warning: this is a very serious route in extremely crevassed terrain.
short_description: A highly crevassed variation of the Vallée Blanche which is not often possible due to the state of the glacier.

name: Vallee Noir via Combe De La Vierge
description: A serious run but one with fun, flowing skiing. From the Helbronner, take in the outstanding views before heading down the mellow slopes to the north, passing between the Aiguilles Marbées and Petit Flambeau. Once past the Petit Flambeau, turn left and ski the mellow slope, staying about 200 - 300 metres east of Petit Flambeau's north ridge, down to the large plateau which marks the meeting point with the classic Vallée Blanche route. (The mellow slope is usually least crevassed on the right hand side initially, and then on the left lower down.)
short_description: Serious glaciers but great flowing skiing brings you from Italy in to the classic French Vallée Blanche.

name: Vallee Blanche
description:
Perhaps a contender for the most famous ski route in the world, the Vallée Blanche offers excellent off-piste skiing in an absolutely breathtaking setting. Whilst requiring only moderate technical skiing ability, the environment is very serious and should not be underestimated; it is not maintained, secured or controlled, and the route follows extremely crevassed terrain.  People die here every year and you should only set off if you have the necessary skills, experience and equipment for skiing on a glacier.  The route is long and excellent weather is required to complete the route safely; this is no place for bad weather or poor visibility. If you have any doubt, hire a mountain guide. Make your way down the north ridge of the Aiguille du Midi, which is equipped with a handrail during the winter season but is still exposed! Get your skis on at the broad col at the foot of the ridge. Head down onto the massive plateau of the Col du Midi but keep your speed up to get across to the Col du Gros Rognon. Flowing glaciated terrain leads you under the impressive east face of the Mont Blanc du Tacul. Bear left down the fall line past crevasses before traversing left towards the Petit Rognon. Keep to the left of the impressive Seracs du Geant following a broad couloir to a flattening. Cross the flattening diagonally rightwards to get round the heavily crevassed terrain below. Follow the easy angled wide glacier back to Montenvers. You can take the stairs to the Telecabine Mer du Glace or continue further down the glacier to hike up to the James Bond track (the windy forest track which leads back to Chamonix town centre.) Hiking the stairs up the Montenvers takes around 10 minutes, allow 20 for the hike up from the glacier to the start of the James Bond track. 
NB: There is no precise line to take and the line on the map only shows the general direction.  Conditions on the glacier will dictate the route required.
short_description: Perhaps the most famous ski descent in the world? Technically moderate but very serious skiing in an absolutely breathtaking setting.

name: Tour Ronde South Couloir to Brenva Glacier
description: extreme
short_description: extreme

name: Vecchio Skilift Couloir
description: Although rarely in condition, this line is worth seeking out when it is. The top is often rocky and the line is steep throughout.
short_description: One for those who like it extreme, this alternative entry to the Dario couloir is both steep and committing.

name: Scala couloir
description: Make your way to the stairs above the Toula glacier and instead of taking them down to the glacier traverse left and find the slope which leads you directly to the glacier below. The route is not often in condition and whilst next to some stairs it is still a serious bit of skiing.
short_description: A short couloir offering an alternative to taking the stairs to the Toula Glacier.

name: Lognan Cables
description: A fun but slightly broken line through the trees of the lower part of Les Grands Montets. Ski under the Lognan cable car cables and gradually drift right, staying to the right of a deep rocky gully throughout, to rejoin the pierre à ric piste.
short_description: Challenging skiing down the steep scrubby shoulder beneath the Lognan telepherique cables

name: Trient via Les Tornays
description: Although serious, this is a must for anyone with the necessary skill and experience. Hike from the top of the Tête de Balme chairlift to the summit of L'Arolette traverse on skis to the col to the north before side stepping up onto the west face of the Pointe du Van. Ski the west flank tending right to the west col and from here enter the wide open bowl. The right side of the col tends to be corniced and is often windloaded. Ski the open bowl which narrows lower down to the valley floor before returning to Trient.
short_description: A serious but fantastic route with a combination of fast, flowing skiing and some steep narrow sections.

name: Pavillon Descents to La Pallud
description: Leaving the Pavillon station traverse around the right side of the building before skiing the small slope to the side of the avalanche barriers. At this point the route splits in three. The right is the most committing and steep, taking a large gully straight down the ridge and to the valley floor. The central option skis the ridge before tending left and then right to take a track through the woods and eventually down on to the valley floor before coming back to the mid station. The left line traverses hard left off the ridge across an open glade to an outcropping of trees. From here descend to the left slightly and find the entrance to a fun couloir and descend to the the valley floor and return, traversing to the right to La Palud.
short_description: Great, varied but serious skiing offering steep to very steep options in a mostly forested area; this route is great in bad weather but not always in condition and often threatened by avalanches.

name: Rochers Rouge
description: Ski c.200 metres down the Chamois piste past the entrance to the Lavancher and then drop off left into a vague bowl. Pick a line down this - there are many possible variations.
short_description: Lots of possible lines offering good variations to the main Lavancher bowl lines with many interesting bumps and rolls.

name: Faux col
description: Where the Charles-Bozon piste heads right at some small cliffs at c.2450 metres, branch off left and follow bowls and ridges to an awkward step. Scuttle down this and head right. Side step up right to find the entrance to the Faux Col. It has a steep and narrow start before opening out and rejoining the piste.
short_description: A wide open col leads to a classic off piste jaunt which leads back to the piste.

name: Hotel face
description: Where the Charles-Bozon piste heads right at some small cliffs at c.2450 metres, branch off left and follow bowls and ridges to an awkward step. Scuttle down this and head right. Side step up right and contour round on the North side past the entrance to Faux Col. Continue under a small summit to a flattening and then sidestep up east over a bump to the rocky entrance of the Hotel Face. Once at the top of the face, simply pick the best line - there are plenty of options.
short_description: “THE classic freeride face at Brévent which offers numerous different routes of varying difficulty”.

name: Tedesco Couloir
description: Steep and committing skiing for experts only, this short, steep couloir leads to the Toula Glacier. It lies further left again than the Scala couloir and takes you directly to the glacier below but be warned, it skis beautifully yet is prone to windloading and avalanches.
short_description: Another short but steep couloir leading to the Toula Glacier.

name: Requin hut Couloirs
description: Before the final left traverse of the Grand Envers scope out the conditions of these east facing couloirs. With good snow cover these lines offer great skiing down steep sided couloirs before exiting back onto the classic Vallée Blanche line.
short_description: Two sustained and serious exit couloirs that offer steep skiing for those in search of an interesting finish to the Grand Envers.

name: Petit Rognon south-east
description: From the shoulder of the Petit Rognon ski the steep, sunny often crevassed slopes to the right of the Rognon to meet the classic Vallée Blanche line.
short_description: A steep south facing slope is a great finishing option to the classic Vallée Blanche.

name: Tabé Bowl
description: From the top of the Tabé chairlift, ski down a broad ridge just to skier's left of the chairlift cables. When the ridge ends, drop right into the broad gully below and ski down to the Plan Joran restaurant.
short_description: A small open bowl between the trees; often bumpy but usually good fun.

name: Poubelles Couloir Aiguille Du Midi
description: Made famous in the film the "Blizzard of Ahhhs". Rarely in condition, this is incredibly steep line starts just out of the Aiguille du Midi ice cave entrance.  It gets it's name from the French for dustbin as this was once upon a time the rubbish shoot.  The line has a rock band in the middle and needs very good snow cover.  Whilst short, a fall here would be serious.  The bergshrund is also often quite open at the bottom.
short_description: Almost never in condition, a short but steep ski through rocks leads to the glacier.

name: Point du Van Couloir
description: The Van couloirs are all steep, serious and avalanche prone - skiing them requires a great deal of experience. In the right conditions they offer an incredible descent with sections of 50 degree skiing.  Hike from the Tête de Balme chairlift to L'Arolette summit. Traverse high round to the col before side stepping up onto the west face of the Pointe du Van. Contour round to the north face and enter the couloir from the shoulder. The initial wide slopes narrow through a short technical rock band. Ski the remainder of the couloir which is tight, narrow and serious. The slopes open in the bottom allowing fast flowing freeride! Traverse back to Trient via the Ski du Fond track.
short_description: A wild, steep and serious descent for experts only.

name: Petit Rognon north-east
description: From the shoulder of the Petit Rognon ski the shaded slopes to the left of the Rognon to meet the classic Vallée Blanche line.
short_description: Moderate angled skiing leads you back to the Vallee Blanche, this line usually holds powder well due to its northerly aspect.

name: Petit Envers du Plan
description: A great variation on the classic Vallée Blanche offering wide open steeper skiing options and excellent off-piste skiing in an absolutely breathtaking setting. The environment is very serious and should not be underestimated; the route is not maintained, secured or controlled and follows extremely crevassed terrain.  People die here every year and you should only set off if you have the necessary skills, experience and equipment for skiing on a glacier.  The route is long and excellent weather is required to complete the route safely; this is no place for bad weather or poor visibility. If you have any doubt, hire a mountain guide. Make your way down the north ridge of the Aiguille du Midi, which is equipped with a handrail during the winter season but is still exposed! Get your skis on at the broad col at the foot of the ridge.  Traverse down left to another col and follow the plateau and slope to the left of the ridge below. Slopes lead down to a plateau which one usually exits in to the left. This terrain changes rapidly each year but follow weaknesses through the crevasses down to the next plateau. Follow open slopes down to the Petit Rogon. This is a great spot to have lunch and decide which exit you want to choose below.
short_description: Highly crevassed but good skiing, this is a step up from the Vallée Blanche both technically and in the seriousness of the glacier.

name: Fredo
description: An alternative approach to the lower Canadian Bowl; this line starts close to the Herse chairlift cables.
short_description: An alternative approach to the lower Canadian Bowl; usually bumps at the top

name: Fillot
description: Slyly crosses the ridge from the Bochard to find fine slopes on skier's right of the Lavancher bowl
short_description: Slyly crosses the ridge from the Bochard to find fine slopes on skier's right of the Lavancher bowl

name: Passerelle Couloir Helbronner
description: A mega classic, narrow and steep, this is a real testpiece and gem in the crown that is the Hellbronner. Ski the impressive couloir and join the Toula glacier descent heading back to the mid station.
short_description: This narrow, steep and committing couloir offers extreme skiing right off the bridge.

name: Passerelle Couloir
description: Very steep and extreme skiing, accessible with 3 long committing rappels. Start this extreme run by first making three airy and committing 60 meter rappels from the bridge which divides the 2 sections of the  Aiguille du midi lift station. Once in the couloir itself the skiiing is very steep and narrow. After the steep section. the couloir backs off slightly and widens before you join the Glacier rond.
short_description: Very steep, serious and extreme skiing, accessible with 3 long rappels.

name: Para Face
description: The terrain is serious and avalanche prone and the end usually requires some combat skiing, bushwacking or at worst some hiking. From the old Station on the ridge take a hard left. Many options exit in this flowing terrain but make sure to traverse back to the old mid station lift before the terrain gets tight, steep and incredibly hard to navigate. From the station take your skis off and take the summer hiking trail which starts on the left of the building down to the valley floor. Allow 30-40 Minutes.
short_description: A great option for skiing to the valley floor after a descent of any of the west or north face routes off of the Aiguille du Midi

name: Pre Du Rocher Right
description: Chamonix doesn't have much tree skiing but this may be some of the best.  The terrain is wild and serious and can be hard to navigate. From Plan de L'Aiguille link gullies, bowls and rolling terrain to the head of a large bowl. Follow this into the forest then traverse right into the bed of the gully. After a short pitch traverse left back into the forest. Follow the clearing which then leads you back right and down through open glades to a 4x4 track. This zig zags back to the parking lot.  Whilst much of the skiing is in the trees, there is still avalanche risk on the route.
short_description: Wild, serious skiing away from the pisted areas in the trees which is often good when visibility is low.

name: Jeurs bowls
description: Enjoyable off-piste skiing but be aware of the avalanche risk in this sector. From the Tête de Balme lift follow the back bowls through flowing terrain and narrow gullies.  Don’t get too carried away and go too low as you will need to traverse back through the woods back to the Tete de Balme lift.
short_description: This run offers great off piste skiing in relatively gentle undulating terrain.

name: Pre Du Rocher Left
description: A good descent on wide open slopes, but be warned, you pay the price with the exit.  From Plan de L'Aiguille turning right as you leave the station head towards the glaciers. Ski the broad gulley to the right of the lateral moraine. Keep an eye out for the hiking trail that breaks right into the forest. This zigzags through complicated terrain slowly leading you to the 4x4 track and your descent to Chamonix.  The descent is completely away from the ski resort and complete uncontrolled.  The terrain is steep and avalanche prone, particularly at the top.
short_description: A good descent on wide open slopes, but be warned you pay the price with the exit

name: Col du Brevent
description: Where the Charles-Bozon piste heads right at some small cliffs at c.2450 metres, branch off left and follow bowls and ridges to an awkward step. Scuttle down this and head right. Side step up right to find the entrance to the Faux Col. Continue under a small summit, then bear right into a vague couloir which becomes the Col du Brévent. The couloir starts softly then steepens as it traverses right to find the exit couloir and back to the piste. Like most of these lines there is avalanche risk, but more significantly this line overhangs a Blue piste... take great caution not to trigger anything here.
short_description: A big couloir taking you back to the resort, well worth the extra work needed to hike.

name: Lavancher
description: Ski down the Chamois piste and cut left off this when it turns hard rightwards. Traverse left into the large bowl and pick a line down this - there are many possible variations.
short_description: A great alternative to the main bowl lines with fantastic skiing and reliable powder.

name: Lanchers couloir
description: From the top of the Index chairlift hang a left following either the Lachenal piste or the Combe Lachenal freeride line. Where the Lachenal piste heads back left take this fall line couloir until you meet the Les Praz black piste.
short_description: A great extension from the Lachenal bowl that leads to the valley floor.

name: L'Arolette Couloir
description: Hike from the Tête de Balme chairlif to the summit of L'Arolette then enter the steep North facing couloir and ski it into the Jeurs bowl. Take the flowing terrain back left into the woods and return to the Tête de Balme lift.  Beware as these steeper faces in the Le Tour back bowls are notorious for avalanches.
short_description: Giving 600 meters of fantastic skiing, this is worth the hike.

name: Helbronner Cables
description: At the Torino hut exit on to the viewing deck and climb over the fence and click in. Traverse round on to the front face side stepping and down climbing through the narrow rockstep to put you at the top of the cables face. Ski the initial slope before being faced with a left or right option at the small col. Taking the left head fall line down the couloir traversing slightly right halfway down before a final steep couloir and the entrance onto the glacier below. The exit onto the glacier can require a cliff jump early in the season. Ski down the glacier hugging the rocks on the right before skiing down to the mid station. The right option takes down a large open couloir perfect for fast steep skiing before you take a hard left after a large rock outcropping and traverse back to the small couloir and the descent onto the glacier.
short_description: Easily accessible, very serious yet excellent steep skiing below the cables on the Helbronner front face.

name: Gros Rognon
description: Excellent off-piste skiing in an absolutely breathtaking setting. The environment is very serious and should not be underestimated; it is not maintained, secured or controlled, and the route follows extremely crevassed terrain. People die here every year and you should only set off if you have the necessary skills, experience and equipment for skiing on a glacier. The route is long and excellent weather is required to complete the route safely; this is no place for bad weather or poor visibility. If you have any doubt, hire a mountain guide. Make your way down the north ridge of the Aiguille du Midi, which is equipped with a handrail during the winter season but is still exposed! Get your skis on at the broad col at the foot of the ridge. Follow the Vallée Blanche to the Col du Gros Rognon. Traverse high left maintaining your height round onto the east face. From here three excellent options exist that hold great cold snow and bring you back to the classic Vallee Blanche.
short_description: A great variation on the classic Vallée Blanche offering wide open steeper skiing options.

name: Grand Envers
description: A mega classic variation of the Vallee Blanche that links steep sustained pitches before finishing in the Requin Hut exit couloirs. Incredible but very serious skiing. Beware of crevassed areas and avalanche risk, particularly in the first steep pitch. Make your way down the north ridge of the Aiguille du Midi, which is equipped with a handrail during the winter season but is still exposed! Get your skis on at the broad col at the foot of the ridge. Ski along the ridge past the first col and back up onto the next ridge section. Follow this down and holding your speed and nerve get as high as you can back up the next ridge section before sidestepping up a short section. Cut right under the ridge and traverse high to reach the shoulder above a steep triangular NE face. This can hold excellent powder (or windslab!) but also some large crevasses. Ski down into the bowl below and then exit by traversing left out under a rocky spur to another steep shaded slope. Follow the fall line of the next long wide face before exiting again left under a steep ridge. Ski down and left again to lower angle slopes. Traverse left under the next impressive rock face. The entirety of this itinerary is on steep glaciers and crevasses open and change on a daily basis, it is a truly adventurous line and not without danger. Follow the line of weakness down gullies and slopes before traversing round left to a final large bowl above the Mer du Glace. Follow this to pick up the classic Vallée Blanche line to finish.
short_description: A mega classic that links steep sustained pitches before finishing in the requin hut exits couloirs. Incredidble but very serious skiing.

name: Demi-lune
description: Where the Charles-Bozon piste heads right at some small cliffs at c.2450 metres, branch off left and follow a broad ridge. Hold your height and veer right passing two prominent rocks to the entrance. Ski the wide open couloir returning back to the piste.
short_description: A fun excursion a short way from the piste.

name: Glacier Rond
description: Head out of the Midi station and down the ridge. Traverse under the south face of the Aiguille du Midi towards the Refuge des Cosmiques. Traverse under the small rock band below the tiny Abri Simond hut. Side step up to a small col just to the left of the Abri Simond. Make an exposed and sometimes rocky traverse rightwards to reach the top of the Glacier Rond. The face can offer amazing skiing in committing terrain but is very much extreme skiing. The line should be approached cautiously as it is often icy at the top and a fall here could be fatal. Traverse the ridge to the left and ski the prominent spine below the tower.  Descend the face. Shortly after the rimaye traverse left into the top of the exit couloir. (The terrain below this ends in a giant serac so make sure you don't go past the exit couloir.) The entrance to the exit couloir is often rocky and may require side stepping or down-climbing. Ski the large couloir all the way to the Glacier des Bossons where you rejoin the exit of the Cosmiques Couloir.
short_description: A mythical run down a hanging glacier overlooking Chamonix, the steep and serious the first pitch is often icy and has lead to many an accident.

name: Dario Couloir
description: EXPERTS ONLY. Leave the Helbronner top station and start out toward the Col de Flambeaux. Almost straight away turn left and head for the rock outcrop at the start of the couloir. Steep and often with a large cornice at the entrance this is truly an exciting outing. Join the Toula glacier descent.
short_description: Sustained, serious and steep skiing in a fantastic couloir leading to the Toula Glacier below.

name: Croix de Fer Couloir
description: These couloirs are serious and only for experienced skiers.  Avalanches are common here. In the right conditions however, they offer excellent skiing. Hike from the Tête de Balme chairlift to L'Arolette summit. Traverse high round under the Croix de Fer to the col. Descend into this steep and exciting couloir and follow it all the way to the valley floor. A wild and adventurous line.
short_description: Steep, very serious and sustained skiing leads you to the village of Trient.

name: Eugster diagonal
description: VERY EXTREME skiing.  Danger of death; be sure of conditions before you set off. A fall at any time in the route would almost certainly be fatal. Descend the narrow face below you sticking to the side of the rocky outcrop before going going slightly left as the angle backs off. Another small pitch leads you into steepening terrain at which point traversing hard right will bring you into a rock garden and eventually a steep narrow gully leading you to the small col. Take a left here and ski the couloir until it cliffs out below you. Build a rappel anchor on the rock wall on skiers right of the couloir and make a full 60 meter rappel. From here ski diagonally left into another small couloir and a short rappel at the end of this section. Now in the main gully, ski the fall line negotiating a few small rock steps until the Cosmique couloir return track is reached. Relax, breathe and head right and back to the lift station.
short_description: Some of the steepest and most serious terrain accessible from a lift anywhere in the world; an undertaking reserved for only the very best skiers.

name: Envers du Plan
description: Another variation on the classic Vallée Blanche offering wide open steeper skiing options. Excellent off-piste skiing in an absolutely breathtaking setting. The environment is very serious and should not be underestimated; it is not maintained, secured or controlled, and the route follows extremely crevassed terrain. People die here every year and you should only set off if you have the necessary skills, experience and equipment for skiing on a glacier. The route is long and excellent weather is required to complete the route safely; this is no place for bad weather or poor visibility. If you have any doubt, hire a mountain guide. Make your way down the north ridge of the Aiguille du Midi, which is equipped with a handrail during the winter season but is still exposed! Get your skis on at the broad col at the foot of the ridgeTraverse down left to another col and ski the slopes diagonally leftwards to short steep pitch that exits on a series of gullies below. Depend of the state of the crevasses choose a line down and exit left onto the plateau below. Join the Petit Envers and choose between the south-east and north-east lines around the Petit Rognon.
short_description: Great skiing links sections of steeper technical terrain with wide open stretches. Perfect for taking in the view.

name: Dome Traverse
description: An alternative to the main Dome line.
short_description: An alternative to the main Dome line.

name: E.N.S.A Couloir
description: A super classic. After leaving the piste off the Brevent summit locate the obvious brêche at the start of the couloir. There is a small steep step just before entrance. Once through the initial steep section, sometimes requiring a abseil/rappel (35m), ski the superb couloir which offers a great introduction to Chamonix steep skiing. As you descend the couloir the angle kicks back and it widens offering great freeride terrain after a spicy start. Ski to the valley floor before following the walkers trail back to the Planpraz telecabin.  Be aware of avalanche risk in the couloir and all the way down the route.  The south facing aspect means you need to choose your timing wisely.
short_description: Steep and serious terrain reached easily from the Brevent cable car, in a nutshell what Chamonix steep skiing is about.

name: Cosmiques Couloir
description: Serious extreme skiing.  A Chamonix MEGA classic and as good as it gets. 900 meters of sustained and serious terrain between 40-50 degrees. Head out of the Midi station and down the ridge. Traverse under the south face of the Aiguille du Midi towards the Refuge des Cosmiques. From the col to the right of the refuge take a look down into this impressive couloir. Usually two long rappels are required to get down the initial steep rocky section. Once established in the couloir follow the fall line! It starts off steeply and only relents a few degrees over the whole length... a truly epic experience. A couple of short rock steps can exist in the middle which can be avoided by a traverse on the left. At about 2/3 of the way down the couloir splits, and then the left branch splits again. All the options are excellent and the conditions can dictate which you take. When you cross the rimaye and hit the Glacier des Bossons head down the right side keeping hard under the rocks where the glacier becomes heavily crevassed. Traverse right across the next series of faces (called the Para faces after the old lift station - consider carefully the snow stability of these faces before engaging in the Cosmiques couloir) and keeping height and sidestepping where necessary all the way under the north face of the Aiguille du Midi. Variations exist depending on the snow cover. This brings one to the head of the Glacier des Pelerins which is followed down its right side back to the Plan de l'Aiguille.  Be sure that the route is in condition as this is not the place to be at the wrong time.  The face gets the sun in the afternoon and is often frozen in the morning.  Be sure that the exit is also in condition.
short_description: Extreme skiing - 900 meters of sustained and serious terrain between 40-50 degrees; enough to get anyones heart pumping.

name: Col du Plan
description: VERY EXTREME skiing.  Danger of death.  The "intro" to the north face of the Midi. Incredible ambiance and surprisingly "freerideable" in the upper section. The direct entrance to this line is rarely in condition and often fresh snow hides large areas of ice. The slope is very avalanche prone.  A fall on this route would almost certainly be fatal.  Head out on the Grand Envers route and instead of skiing the top of the steep first pitch traverse under the ridge line and out onto the north slope. Ski a short pitch and traverse right underneath the rock outcrop.  A steep face is reached and should be skied cautiously as it is often rocky and the snowpack very thin. Just above the rimaye the terrain angle kicks back and some incredible turns can be had in an awe inspiring setting.  Ski the large bowl heading right before the serac and locate a rock outcrop where you need to build a rap station. A full 60 meter or two 30 meter rappels only just puts you at the top of a narrow couloir. Ski this until a small rock step. Rappel once more before enjoying the wide open slope that take you back to the midi mid station.
short_description: The "intro" to the north face of the Midi with an incredible ambiance and surprisingly "freerideable" skiing in the upper section.

name: Cesso Plus Couloir
description: Extreme skiing. EXPERTS ONLY. A steep variant in to the Cesso couloir which is not often in condition. Half way down the Cesso take a hard left over the exposed ridge and enter the top of the very steep Cesso Plus. Steep and committing skiing awaits but beware of the rock section lower down especially early in the season.
short_description: A steep variant into the Cesso couloir it is not often in condition but it's good when it is.

name: Col D'Entreves
description: Follow the Aiguille D'Entreves line to the Col d'Entreves. From the col find a way through the often corniced entrance. Trend right across the rock bands to enter the couloir. Ski this down onto the wide and steep Glacier d'Entrèves. This narrows and steepens again before one can traverse hard left under the lowest rocks, under the Glacier de Toule and across the slopes to rejoin the Glacier de Toule line back to Pavillon.
short_description: A wild setting sets the tone for an incredible descent, steep and committing.

name: Cesso Couloir
description: Extreme skiing. EXPERTS ONLY. Accessed by leaving the Hellbronner top station and traversing back hard right and under the cables. This is a fantastic descent offering big turn potential in the upper slope and technical skiing lower down once it steepens and narrows. Joins the Toula classic descent.
short_description: Wide to start with, the Cesso narrows in its lower reaches and is exciting as you ski between her steep rock walls.

name: Combe de la Gliere
description: From the top of the Col Cornu chairlift skin up to the col Cornu itself. Traverse the north face of the Aiguille Pourrie (watch out for windloaded slopes) to gain the entrance to the Col de la Glière. A beautiful mellow bowl, steep for the first few turns leads you back to the piste.
short_description: Skiing from a wide col with space for a lot of skiers; fresh tracks are almost guaranteed.

name: Bozon Couloir
description: From the flat area at the top of the Parsa chairlift head west and enter the prominent couloir. Ski the wide perfect freeride terrain which narrows to a technical finish. Join the Couloir Allais exit.
short_description: Good skiing awaits in this classsic couloir which holds snow well until late in the day due to its westerly aspect

name: Col du Balme to Trient
description: From the Col drag lift hike to the Col de Balme. Access the col and ski the wide open valley all the way to Trient. This itinerary holds powder incredibly well yet is very exposed to all the avalanche terrain above on several aspects. The skiing is never very steep but beware of avalanche risk from the steeper slopes above you.  The route finishes in Trient (Switzerland) from where you will need to get a bus back to Le Tour.
short_description: A real treat with easy access, varied terrain and descent options.

name: Descent to Châtelard
description: A real adventure taking you well away from the lift system, linking bowls and steep faces all the way to the town of Châtelard. Hike from the Tête de Balme to L'Arolette summit. Traverse high round to the col before side stepping up onto the west face of the Pointe du Van. Turn left to ski the weakness down the face leading into the forest below.  The route links open meadows with tight forested terrain before arriving at a reservoir. From here start traversing right on a hiking trail back to Châtelard. You do not finish at the lifts and will need to get the bus/train to rejoin the resort.
short_description: A real adventure linking bowls and steep faces all the way to the town of Châtelard.

name: Chamonix Return
description: From the exit point of the Bossons Glacier walk across the road and put your skis on at the little green bridge. Ski this first slope and link trails and walking paths until you arrive back at the roundabout just before the town of Chamonix. This route can often times be very rocky and unpleasant and require a lot of walking.
short_description: A series of walking trails makes it possible to ski from the tunnel du Mont Blanc back to chamonix if there is enough snow.

name: Cirque de Catogne
description: Hike from the Tête de Balme to L'Arolette summit. Traverse high round to the West facing slopes. Ski the face into the Jeurs bowl before returning to the lift through the woods.
short_description: A wide open face offering good skiing far from the crowds.

name: Bossons glacier exit
description: After finishing the one of the classic couloirs from above and just after starting the traverse back to the Midi mid station take a left and ski down a short pitch which leads you towards the Bossons glacier. Always staying just to the right of the glacier itself descend until near the snout of the glacier before going hard left onto the glacier itself. The route varies drastically here from year to year but locate a safe passage from the glacier onto the snowy slopes below. This may involve down climbing and/or rappelling. Once off the glacier ski fall line for a short pitch or two before taking the left facing slopes into the valley below.  Follow this until it narrows and a walkers path is found which takes you back to the parking lot for the tunnel du Mont Blanc. Take the Chamonix return route from here if there is enough snow or hitch back to town.
short_description: A serious direct finish to the Rond or Cosmiques couloir this route is great skiing when snow conditions allow.

name: Bellin Couoir
description: Whilst easily accessible this line should not be underestimated.  When conditions are sure and you are comfortable skiing in this steep terrain, this gem of a run starts by following the Charles Bozon piste. After the col which the piste passes through, continue straight under the Brévent east face and enter the top of the couloir. The descent is narrow and impressive in its constant steep angle. Keep on the left through the middle section to avoid a small cliff section. The couloir widens and after traversing left the Planpraz parking area is reached.  The south facing aspect means you need to choose your timing wisely.
short_description: Steep and serious skiing under the very impressive Brévent cliff face.

name: secret
description: secret
short_description: secret

name: Crochues Bowl
description: Traverse from the Index lift to the base of the Floria tow. Head in an easterly direction to the rolling terrain and rocky couloirs until you meet the Floria piste.
short_description: The bowl offers unlimited descent options in flowy terrain.

name: Col du Belvedere
description: From the top of the Floria draglift, traverse around Combe des Aiguilles Crochues, holding as much height as possible, until at the foot of the long blunt ridge above the Cabane de la Tête Aubuy. Sidestep/shuffle uphill for 10 vertical metres to a large flat area. Put skins on here and climb up to Lac Blanc, which is completely frozen in winter. Cross the Lac and make a long and beautiful ascent up to the Col du Belvédère. On the north side of the Col is a narrow and very steep (c.50 degrees) couloir, which can be side slipped but is abseiled by most parties using an in-situ bolted anchor. (The abseil requires at least 2 50 metre ropes but 60's are better.) From the bottom of the abseil there is another bolted anchor on the left (when facing downhill) that allows for another abseil down the 45 degree slope below but most people ski (or sideslip!) from the bottom of the first abseil. Either option leads to gradually the gradually mellowing slopes of the Glacier de Bérard and, after this, the Bérard valley itself. Descend to the tree line and then stay right of the river and ski to the hamlet of Le Buet via a good track and the occasional tricky section of tight tree skiing. From Le Buet, take the train back to Les Praz and the Flégère carpark.
access: Take the Index then Floria Drag lift. Then traverse beneath the Crochues Ridges and skin up the Col.
short_description: A Chamonix classic which features a beautiful ascent, an exciting, long abseil and some stunning north facing bowls.

name: Vallee Noir via Glacier du Géant
description: From the Helbronner head out left to the Col des Flambeaux. From the Col ski just to the left of the fall-line to reach a plateau. Traverse across the plateau and ski the vague shallow gully on the right (this section often holds good cold snow) down the fall line into the main Vallée Blanche basin and join the classic Vallée Blanche.
short_description: A moderate and fun line down some serious glaciated terrain on the Italian side of the Vallée Blanche.

name: Couloir Domenech
description:
This couloir is hidden deeply up the Miage glacier. It is not often repeated since it's extremely steep and narrow and usually some parts are too dry to be skied. Furthermore, just to the side of this line there is the well known Bonatti couloir which attracts more people.
This couloir can be reached by Arp lift. Leaving the lift stay on your right without loosing height to reach the ridge. Here keep traversing on your left until reaching a flat part, where with your skins or walking (10 mins) you will arrive on a flat bowl. Put your skis on and start descending keeping your left. until reaching a small bridge. Put your skins back on and start climbing up right in front of you to enter Miage glacier. In 1 - 1.5 hours you will reach the base of the couloir, where the true fatigue will start! You will have to bootpack the 1000 metre couloir, with the cold north wind coming down from it.

In the middle of the couloir there can be a rocky step for which a 30 metre rope can be useful

The way back follows the glacial moraine, just follow back your skin track until you reach the bridge. Here continue following the evident road that will bring you to Val Very lifts. The lifts close at 4.30 pm, but you can also keep skiing the road in order to reach the Courmayeur parking area.
short_description: A long and steep couloir

content_proofreading.reason: The approach description needs to be more clear and have concrete details. Also, is it really possible to ski down Val Veny back to the parking area? I don't remember this being possible.
